posts.name: ericjanofski
posts.cooked:
Hey all, we have named command that positions our bot based off of an april tag. In path planner, we have PATH1 that drives us close to the april tag, then we run this command to get us to the exact position to score, then we run PATH2 which takes us elsewhere. Since we’ve moved with the named command, our bot is no longer on the end of PATH1 nor is it at the beginning of PATH2. Pathplanner shows a yellow warning sign since we started PATH2 where we expect the custom command to bring us.

Is this okay to do? Should we expect PATH2 will start and our bot will just race to catch up to the path as it progresses? Any suggestions on how to handle this better?

posts.name: Lavi Arzi
posts.cooked: Well isn’t the ending location of the custom command the same as the starting location of path2?

posts.name: ericjanofski
posts.cooked: yes, but pathplanner has no idea what that custom command does, so there’s a gap between the end of PATH1 and the start of PATH2. Pathplanner shows a yellow warning sign. I also don’t know the EXACT end of the custom command, so it’s just an estimation.

posts.name: Jason
posts.cooked: We are attempting to do the same thing by running a namedcommand to align the robot with the reef more accurately but still want to use the paths, did your team ever figure out what would happen or do any testing?

posts.name: Val
posts.cooked: Pathplanner will start the target pose at the start of the PATH2, The position pid loop should correct for it if the difference if relatively small. This is what we do in order to get back to the coral station since we use an auto-align system!

posts.name: ericjanofski
posts.cooked: Yep, it worked great. Pid makes it catch up. Pathplanner is nothing short of wonderful

posts.name: Aditya Gajula
posts.cooked:
Did you use the custom align command (which I assume uses pid controllers) as a NamedCommand and run it at the end of PATH1?

Also, did the yellow warning sign prevent you from following the auto or did you get rid of it somehow?

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
Aditya9246:

Also, did the yellow warning sign prevent you from following the auto or did you get rid of it somehow?

The warning is just to bring attention to gaps in between paths that could cause accuracy issues if they were followed as-is. If you are doing something like an alignment command in between that will close that gap then you can ignore the warning.
